chapter.title: CHAPTER ONE
chapter.name: Observing the Armies on the Battlefield of Kurukṣetra
chapter.source_note: Original text provided by user and parsed into structured fields.

verses.heading: TEXT 1
word_meaning_lines: dhåtaräñöraù—King Dhåtaräñöra; uväca—said;
dharma-kñetre—in the place of pilgrimage; kuru-kñetre—in Kurukṣetra;
samavetäù—assembled; yuyutsavaù—desiring to fight; mämakäù—my sons;
päëòaväù—the sons of Pāṇḍu; ca—and; eva—certainly; kim—what; akurvata—did they do;
saïjaya—O Saïjaya.
verses.translation: Dhåtaräñöra said: O Saïjaya, after assembling in the place of pilgrimage at Kurukṣetra, what did my sons and the sons of Pāṇḍu do, being desirous to fight?
purport_paragraphs: Bhagavad-gītā is theistic science; one should read it with a bona fide devotee to avoid motivated interpretations. The Gītā encompasses Vedic wisdom and is directly spoken by Lord Kṛṣṇa.

The dialogue between Dhṛtarāṣṭra and Sañjaya frames the Mahābhārata; Kurukṣetra is a sacred battlefield and setting for the Lord's guidance. Dhṛtarāṣṭra feared the holy place might favor the Pāṇḍavas; Sañjaya, by Vyāsa's mercy, could see the battlefield and report.

verses.heading: TEXT 2
word_meaning_lines: saïjayaù—Saïjaya; uväca—said; dåñṭvä—after seeing; tu—but; päëòava-anékam—the Pāṇḍava army;
vyuòham—arranged in phalanx; duryodhanaù—King Duryodhana; tadā—at that time;
ācāryam—the teacher (Droṇa); upasaṁgamya—approaching; rājā—the king; vacanam—words; abravīt—spoke.
verses.translation: Saïjaya said: O King, after looking over the army gathered by the sons of Pāṇḍu, King Duryodhana went to his teacher and began to speak the following words:
purport_paragraphs: Dhṛtarāṣṭra lacked spiritual vision; Sañjaya relayed events. Duryodhana, alarmed at the Pāṇḍava arrangement, sought counsel of his commander Droṇa.

verses.heading: TEXT 3
word_meaning_lines: paśya—behold; etām—this; pāṇḍu-putrāṇām—of the sons of Pāṇḍu; ācārya—O teacher;
mahatīm—great; camūm—army; vyūḍhām—arranged; drupada-putreṇa—by Drupada's son (Dhṛṣṭadyumna); tava śiṣyeṇa—your disciple; dhīmatā—very intelligent.
verses.translation: O teacher, behold the great army of the sons of Pāṇḍu, so expertly arranged by your intelligent disciple, the son of Drupada.
purport_paragraphs: Duryodhana sought to highlight Droṇa's leniency: though Droṇa had enmity with Drupada, he trained Drupada's son Dhṛṣṭadyumna, who now arranges Pāṇḍava forces—this is a political and tactical criticism.

verses.heading: TEXT 4
word_meaning_lines: atra—here; śūrāḥ—heroes; maheṣvāsaḥ—mighty bowmen; bhīma-arjuna—Bhīma and Arjuna;
samāḥ—equal; yudhi—in battle; yuyudhānaḥ—Yuyudhāna; virāṭaḥ—Virāta; drupadaḥ—Drupada; mahā-rathaḥ—great chariot-warrior.
verses.translation: Here in this army there are many heroic bowmen equal in fighting to Bhīma and Arjuna; there are also great fighters like Yuyudhāna, Virāta and Drupada.
purport_paragraphs: Duryodhana lists formidable warriors to justify his fear; he compares several commanders to the greatest Pāṇḍava heroes.

verses.heading: TEXT 5
word_meaning_lines: dhṛṣṭaketuḥ—Dhṛṣṭaketu; cekitānaḥ—Cekitāna; kāśirājaḥ—King of Kaśī; vīryavān—valiant;
purujit—Purujit; kuntibhojaḥ—Kuntibhoja; śaibyaḥ—Śaibya; nara-puṅgavaḥ—exalted heroes.
verses.translation: There are also great, heroic, powerful fighters like Dhṛṣṭaketu, Cekitāna, Kaśirāja, Purujit, Kuntibhoja and Śaibya.
purport_paragraphs: Duryodhana enumerates more heroes to bolster his claim of combined might on the Pāṇḍava side.

verses.heading: TEXT 6
word_meaning_lines: yudhamanyuḥ—Yudhamanyu; vikrāntaḥ—mighty; uttamaujaḥ—Uttamauja; vīryavān—valiant;
saubhadraḥ—son of Subhadrā; draupadeyāḥ—sons of Draupadī; sarve—all; mahā-rathāḥ—great chariot-warriors.
verses.translation: There are the mighty Yudhamanyu, the very powerful Uttamauja, the son of Subhadrā and the sons of Draupadī. All these warriors are great chariot fighters.
purport_paragraphs: Even lesser-known names are dangerous; Duryodhana lists them to intimidate Droṇa and Bhīṣma.

verses.heading: TEXT 7
transliteration_lines: ASMaak&- Tau iviXaía Yae TaaiàbaeDa iÜJaaetaMa )
NaaYak-a MaMa SaENYaSYa Sa&jaQa| TaaNb]vqiMa Tae )) 7 ))
word_meaning_lines: asmākam—our; tu—but; viśiṣṭāḥ—especially excellent; ye—those; tān—them; nibodha—know;
dvijottama—best of brāhmaṇas; nāyakā—leaders; mama—my; saṃyasya—army; saṁjñārthaṃ—for information; tām bravīmi te—I tell you them.
verses.translation: O best of the brāhmaṇas, for your information, let me tell you about the captains who are especially qualified to lead my military force.
purport_paragraphs: Duryodhana formally addresses the teacher (Droṇa) to name his chosen commanders.

verses.heading: TEXT 8
word_meaning_lines: bhavān—yourself; bhīṣmaḥ—Bhīṣma; karṇaḥ—Karṇa; kṛpaḥ—Kṛpa; samiti-jayaḥ—always victorious;
aśvatthāmā—Aśvatthāmā; vikarṇa—Vikarṇa; saumadattiḥ—Bhuriśrava (son of Somadatta).
verses.translation: There are personalities like yourself, Bhīṣma, Karṇa, Kṛpa, Aśvatthāmā, Vikarṇa and Bhuriśrava, who are always victorious in battle.
purport_paragraphs: Duryodhana flatters and lists veteran champions to reassure himself and to rally the commanders.

verses.heading: TEXT 9
transliteration_lines: ANYae c bhv éUra MadQaeR TYa¢-JaqivTaa )
word_meaning_lines: anye—many others; ca—also; bahavaḥ—numerous; śūrāḥ—heroes; mad-arthe—for my sake; tyakta-jīvitaḥ—ready to risk life;
nānā-āsastra—many weapons; praharaṇaḥ—equipped; sarve—all yuddha-viśāradaḥ—experienced in battle.
verses.translation: There are many other heroes prepared to lay down their lives for me; all are well-equipped with various weapons and experienced in war.
purport_paragraphs: Duryodhana emphasizes committed followers willing to die for him, reinforcing his belief in victory by numbers and devotion.

verses.heading: TEXT 10
word_meaning_lines: aparyāptam—immeasurable; tat—that; asmākam—our (strength); balaṁ—force; bhīṣma- abhirakṣitam—protected by Bhīṣma;
paryāptam—sufficient/limited; tv—but; idam—this; eteṣām—theirs; balaṁ—force; bhéma- abhirakṣitam—protected by Bhīma.
verses.translation: Our strength is immeasurable, and we are perfectly protected by Bhīṣma, whereas the strength of the Pāṇḍavas, protected by Bhīma, is limited.
purport_paragraphs: Duryodhana compares strengths; he feels secure because of the veteran general Bhīṣma, and disparages Bhīma as less experienced.

verses.heading: TEXT 11
word_meaning_lines: ayaneṣu—in the strategic places; ca—also; sarveṣu—everywhere; yathā-bhāgam—as per their divisions; avasthitāḥ—positioned;
bhīṣmam—Bhīṣma; eva—indeed; abhirakṣantu—let (them) protect; bhavantaḥ—ye (you) all; sarve—each; eva—certainly; hi—for sure.
verses.translation: Now all of you must give full support to Grandfather Bhīṣma, standing at your respective strategic points in the phalanx of the army.
purport_paragraphs: Duryodhana urges all commanders to fully support Bhīṣma — he hopes combined protection will secure victory; he attempts to ensure no one feels slighted.

verses.heading: TEXT 12
word_meaning_lines: tasya—his (Duryodhana's); sañjanayan—increasing; harṣam—joy; kuru-vṛddhaḥ—Kuru's elder (Bhīṣma); pitāmahah—grandfather;
siṃha-nādam—lion-like sound; vinadya—resounding; uccaiḥ—loudly; śaṁkham—conchshell; dadhmau—blew; pratāpavān—the valiant.
verses.translation: Then Bhīṣma, the valiant grandsire of the Kuru dynasty, blew his conchshell very loudly like the sound of a lion, giving Duryodhana joy.
purport_paragraphs: Bhīṣma's conch boosted morale. Symbolically his blast also presages the Lord's presence favoring the Pāṇḍavas, though Bhīṣma intends to encourage his grandson.

verses.heading: TEXT 13
word_meaning_lines: tataḥ—thereafter; śaṁkhāḥ—conchshells; ca—and; bheryāḥ—bugles; paṇava-ānaka—trumpets, drums; go-mukhāḥ—horns; sahasa—suddenly; abhyahanyanta—sounded together; saḥ—this; śabdaḥ—sound; tumulaḥ—tumultuous; abhavat—became.
verses.translation: After that, the conches, bugles, trumpets, drums and horns were all sounded together and the combined sound became tumultuous.
purport_paragraphs: A great uproar of instruments signals the commencement of battle; it affects hearts on both sides and intensifies the scene.

verses.heading: TEXT 14
word_meaning_lines: tataḥ—thereafter; śvetaiḥ hayaiḥ—by white horses; yukte—yoked; mahati syandane—in the great chariot; sthitau—stood; mādhavaḥ—Kṛṣṇa; pāṇḍavaḥ—Arjuna; ca—also; eva—indeed; divyau śaṁkhau—divine conchshells; pradadhmatuḥ—sounded.
verses.translation: On the other side, both Lord Kṛṣṇa and Arjuna, stationed on a great chariot drawn by white horses, sounded their divine conchshells.
purport_paragraphs: Kṛṣṇa and Arjuna blow transcendental conches—this signals spiritual advantage and the presence of fortune with the Pāṇḍavas.

verses.heading: TEXT 15
word_meaning_lines: pāñcajanyam—the conch Pañcajanya (Kṛṣṇa's); hṛṣīkeśaḥ—Hṛṣīkeśa (Kṛṣṇa); devadattam—Devadatta (Arjuna's conch); dhanañjayaḥ—Dhanañjaya (Arjuna); pauṇḍram—Pauṇḍra (Bhīma's); mahā-śaṁkham—great conch; bhīma-karmā—of Bhīma; vrkodaraḥ—Vṛkodara (Bhīma).
verses.translation: Kṛṣṇa blew his conch Pañcajanya, Arjuna blew Devadatta, and Bhīma blew Pauṇḍra—each heroic conch was sounded.
purport_paragraphs: The names and blowing of conches are symbolic: Kṛṣṇa directs senses (Hṛṣīkeśa), Arjuna is Dhanañjaya, Bhīma is Vṛkodara. Their conches inspire troops and denote transcendental support.

verses.heading: TEXT 16
word_meaning_lines: anantavijayam—Anantavijaya (Yudhiṣṭhira's conch); rājā—king; kuntī-putraḥ—son of Kuntī; yudhiṣṭhiraḥ—Yudhiṣṭhira;
nakulaḥ—Nakula; sahadevaḥ—Sahadeva; sughoṣa, maṇipuṣpaka—names of their conches.
verses.translation: King Yudhiṣṭhira blew Anantavijaya; Nakula and Sahadeva blew Sughoṣa and Maṇipuṣpaka respectively.
purport_paragraphs: Pāṇḍava leaders and other notable warriors also sounded their conches; the list communicates the full roll of Pāṇḍava champions and their instruments.

verses.heading: TEXT 17
word_meaning_lines: kāśyaḥ—king of Kaśī; parameṣva-āsaḥ—paramount ruler; śikhaṇḍī—great chariot-warrior; mahā-rathaḥ—great fighter;
dhṛṣṭadyumnaḥ—Dhṛṣṭadyumna; virāṭaḥ—Virāṭa; sātyakiḥ—Sātyaki; aparājitaḥ—unconquerable.
verses.translation: Also the King of Kaśī, Śikhaṇḍī, Dhṛṣṭadyumna, Virāṭa and the unconquerable Sātyaki blew their conches.
purport_paragraphs: The Pāṇḍava side contains many kings and unconquerable heroes, adding to their strength and legitimacy.

verses.heading: TEXT 18
word_meaning_lines: drupade—Drupada; draupadeyāḥ—sons of Draupadī; sarvaśaḥ—respectively; pṛthivī-pate—kings of the earth;
saubhadraḥ—son of Subhadrā; mahā-bāhuḥ—mighty-armed; śaṁkhān dadhmuḥ—blew conches separately.
verses.translation: Drupada, the sons of Draupadī, and many great kings and warriors blew their respective conches.
purport_paragraphs: The blow of many conches from kings and great warriors underscores the magnitude of the conflict and Pāṇḍava backing.

verses.heading: TEXT 19
word_meaning_lines: saḥ ghoṣaḥ—this sound; dhṛtarāṣṭrāṇām—of Dhṛtarāṣṭra's sons; hṛdayāni—hearts; vyadārayat—shattered;
nabhaḥ—sky; ca—also; pṛthivī—earth; caiva—also; tumulaḥ—tumultuous; abhy anunādayan—resounded.
verses.translation: The sound of the Pāṇḍava conches was tumultuous and resounded in the sky and on the earth, shattering the hearts of the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra.
purport_paragraphs: The Pāṇḍava sound unnerved the Kurus; Arjuna’s and Kṛṣṇa’s presence had psychological impact on opponents.

verses.heading: TEXT 20
word_meaning_lines: atha—thereupon; vyavasthitān—arranged; draśṭvā—having seen; dhṛtarāṣṭrān—the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra;
kapi-dhvajaḥ—whose flag had Hanumān; pravṛtte—when arrows were about to be released; śastra-sampāte—assembly of weapons;
dhanuḥ udyamya—taking up the bow; pāṇḍavaḥ—Arjuna; hṛṣīkeśam—to Hṛṣīkeśa (Kṛṣṇa); tadā—then; vākyaṁ—words; idam—this; āha—said; mahī-pate—O king.
verses.translation: Seeing the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra arranged, Arjuna, with the Hanumān-banner on his flag, took up his bow and addressed Kṛṣṇa these words.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna prepares to fight and speaks to Kṛṣṇa; the Hanumān emblem signifies protection and link to Rāma’s victory, reinforcing Pāṇḍava confidence.

verses.heading: TEXT 21
word_meaning_lines: arjunaḥ—Arjuna; uväca—said; senayoḥ—of the armies; ubhayor—of both; madhye—in the middle;

ratham—chariot; sthāpaya—place; me—for me; acyuta—O infallible one (Kṛṣṇa); yāvat—as long as; etān—these; nirīkṣe—may behold; aham—I; yoddhu-kāmān—desirous to fight; avasthitān—arranged; kaiḥ—with whom; mayā saha—by me together should be fought; yoddhavyam—be fought; asmin—in this; raṇa-samudyame—assembly of battle.
verses.translation: Arjuna said: O infallible one, place my chariot between the two armies so I may see those present and know with whom I must fight.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna requests Kṛṣṇa to draw the chariot between the armies to survey who is present; the address 'acyuta' affirms Kṛṣṇa's supreme, infallible nature.

verses.heading: TEXT 22
word_meaning_lines: This line continues Arjuna's request: he asks to observe who is assembled and ready to fight, and with whom he should engage.
verses.translation: (continuation) ...so that I may see who is present here, who is desirous of fighting, and with whom I must contend in this great battle attempt.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna's motive is to assess not to initiate peace talks; he wishes to know those he must face, although he is reluctant to fight his kinsmen.

verses.heading: TEXT 23
word_meaning_lines: yotsyamānān—those to be fought; avekṣe—I shall see; aham—I; ye—who; ete—these; atra—here; samāgatāḥ—assembled;
dhṛtarāṣṭrasya—of Dhṛtarāṣṭra; durbuddheḥ—evil-minded; yuddhe—in fight; priya-cikīrṣavaḥ—wishing to please.
verses.translation: Let me see those who are assembled here to fight, who wish to please the evil-minded Dhṛtarāṣṭra.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna recognizes Duryodhana's malicious intent and wishes to see who sides with him; he intends to estimate the moral and practical implications before fighting.

verses.heading: TEXT 24
word_meaning_lines: saïjayaù—Saïjaya; uväca—said; evam uktaḥ—thus addressed; hṛṣīkeśa—Hṛṣīkeśa (Kṛṣṇa); guṇākkeśena—by Arjuna; bhārata—O descendant of Bharata;
senayoḥ—of the armies; ubhayor—of both; madhye—in the middle; sthāpayitvā—having placed; rathottamam—the best chariot.
verses.translation: Sañjaya said: Thus addressed by Arjuna, Hṛṣīkeśa (Kṛṣṇa) placed the excellent chariot in the midst of the two armies.
purport_paragraphs: Kṛṣṇa, understanding Arjuna's request, positions the chariot. The epithet 'Guṇākkeśa' (conqueror of sleep/ignorance) for Arjuna highlights his devotion and awareness.

verses.heading: TEXT 25
word_meaning_lines: bhīṣma—Bhīṣma; droṇa—Droṇa; pramukhatāḥ—at the front; sarveṣām—all; mahī-kṣitām—chiefs of the earth;
uvāca—said; pārtha—O Pārtha (Arjuna); paśyai—see; etān—these; samavetān—assembled; kurūn—the Kurus; iti—thus.
verses.translation: Hṛṣīkeśa said: O Pārtha, behold all the Kurus assembled in the front with Bhīṣma and Droṇa and all chieftains of the earth.
purport_paragraphs: Kṛṣṇa points out the assembled Kurus so Arjuna can see the relatives, teachers, and elders he must face, preparing to address his moral dilemma.

verses.heading: TEXT 26
word_meaning_lines: tatra—there; apaśyat—he saw; sthitān—standing; pārtha—Arjuna; pitṛn—fathers; atha—also; pitämahān—grandfathers;

ācāryān—teachers; mātulān—maternal uncles; bhrātṛn—brothers; putrān—sons; pautrān—grandsons; sakhīn—friends; śvaśurān—fathers-in-law; suhṛdaḥ—well-wishers; caiva—also; senayoḥ ubhayor api—in both armies.
verses.translation: There Arjuna saw standing fathers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, friends and in-laws—members of both armies.
purport_paragraphs: Seeing such intimate relatives on both sides causes Arjuna great grief; the full human cost becomes manifest.

verses.heading: TEXT 27
word_meaning_lines: tān—those; samīkṣya—after seeing; saḥ—he (Arjuna); kaunteyaḥ—son of Kuntī; sarvāṇ—all relatives; avasthitān—present;
kṛpayā—by compassion; parayā—very great; viṣṭaḥ—overwhelmed; viśādaḥ—distress; idam—this; abravīt—he spoke.
verses.translation: Seeing all his relatives Arjuna was overwhelmed by compassion and spoke these words in sorrow.
purport_paragraphs: This is the emotional turning point—Arjuna's compassion leads to moral paralysis and the famous dialogue soon begins.

verses.heading: TEXT 28
transliteration_lines: SaqdiNTa MaMa Gaa}aai<a Mau%& c PairéuZYaiTa )) 28 ))
word_meaning_lines: arjunaḥ—Arjuna; uväca—said; dṛśo-vemam—seeing thus; sva-janam—my relatives; kṛṣṇa—O Kṛṣṇa;
yuyutsum—ready to fight; samupasthitam—present; śedanti—tremble; mama gātrāṇi—my limbs; mukhaṃ ca—my mouth; pariṣuṣyati—becomes dry.
verses.translation: Arjuna said: My dear Kṛṣṇa, seeing my kinsmen present ready to fight, my limbs tremble and my mouth becomes dry.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna's physical symptoms indicate moral distress; his devotion makes him soft-hearted, not weak—this is the start of his renunciation of battle.

verses.heading: TEXT 29
word_meaning_lines: vepathuḥ—trembling; ca—also; śarére—on my body; me—my; roma-harṣaḥ—hairs stand on end; jāyate—occur;
gāṇḍīvam—my bow Gāṇḍīva; sraṁsate—slips; hastāt—from hand; tvak—skin; caiva—also; paridahyate—burning sensation.
verses.translation: My whole body trembles, hairs stand on end, my bow Gāṇḍīva slips from my hand and my skin burns.
purport_paragraphs: Symptoms are those of fear rooted in attachment to life. Arjuna's dissolution shows his human response to the prospect of killing kin.

verses.heading: TEXT 30
transliteration_lines: Na c Xa¥-aeMYavSQaaTau& >a]MaTaqv c Mae MaNa )
word_meaning_lines: na—not; ca—also; śaknomi—am able; avasthātuṁ—to stand; bhramati—my mind reels; iva—as if; ca—also; me—my; manaḥ—mind;
nimittāni—causes; ca—also; paśyāmi—I see; viparītāni—contrary/evil; keśava—O Kṛṣṇa.
verses.translation: I am unable to stand here any longer; my mind is reeling and I foresee only evil, O Keshava (Kṛṣṇa).
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna acknowledges mental breakdown: attachment leads him to see only negative consequences, prompting renunciation of action.

verses.heading: TEXT 31
transliteration_lines: Na k-a¿e ivJaYa& k*-Z<a Na c raJYa& Sau%aiNa c )) 31 ))
word_meaning_lines: na—not; ca—also; śreyaḥ—good; anupaśyāmi—I see not; hatvā—by killing; sva-janam—own kinsmen; ātmané—in my opinion;
na—nor; kāṅkṣe—I desire; vijayam—victory; kṛṣṇa—O Kṛṣṇa; na ca—nor; rājyam—kingdom; sukhāni ca—happiness.
verses.translation: I do not see any good in killing my own kinsmen; I do not desire victory, kingdom or pleasures, O Kṛṣṇa.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna considers killing kin unjustifiable despite kṣatriya duty. He prioritizes moral/relational considerations over political ends, not yet understanding the higher vision.

verses.heading: TEXT 32
transliteration_lines: ik&- Naae raJYaeNa GaaeivNd ik&- >aaeGaEJas„ivTaeNa va )
YaezaMaQaeR k-ax(i+aTa& Naae raJYa& >aaeGaa Sau%aiNa c )) 32 ))
word_meaning_lines: kiṃ—what use; no—to us; rājyeṇa—by kingdom; govinda—O Govinda (Kṛṣṇa); kiṃ—what; bhogaiḥ—enjoyments; jīvitena—by life;
vā—or; yeṣām—of whom; arthe—for whom; kāṅkṣitam—desired; no—our; rājyaṁ—kingdom; bhogāḥ—enjoyments; sukhāni ca—happiness.
verses.translation: O Govinda, of what avail are kingdoms, enjoyments or even life when those for whom we desire them are here ready to sacrifice their lives?
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna argues that worldly gain is meaningless if it requires slaughter of family and friends; he is emotionally and morally opposed to battle.

verses.heading: TEXT 33
transliteration_lines: Ta wMae_viSQaTaa YauÖe Pa[a<aa&STYa¤-a DaNaaiNa c )
word_meaning_lines: taḥ—then; ime—these; avasthitāḥ—standing; yuddhe—in battle; prāṇān—lives; tyaktvā—having given up; dhanāni ca—wealth also;
ācāryāḥ—teachers; pitaraḥ—fathers; putrāḥ—sons; tathāiva ca—also; pitämahāḥ—grandfathers.
verses.translation: These persons, having renounced life and wealth, stand ready in the battle: teachers, fathers, sons and grandfathers.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna enumerates those who will die: it strengthens his resolve to avoid fighting due to human compassion for those relatives.

verses.heading: TEXT 34
word_meaning_lines: mātulāḥ—maternal uncles; śrīrāḥ—fathers-in-law; putrāḥ—sons; śyālāḥ—brothers-in-law; sambandhināḥ—relations;
etān—these; na hantum icchāmi—I do not wish to kill; ghanataḥ api—even though killed; madhusūdana—O Madhusūdana (Kṛṣṇa).
verses.translation: I do not wish to kill these: mothers' brothers, fathers-in-law, sons, brothers-in-law and relatives, O Madhusūdana.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna appeals by naming categories of kin, stressing the moral cost of killing kin even for cosmic or political gains.

verses.heading: TEXT 35
word_meaning_lines: api—even; trailokya-rājyasya—for the sovereignty of the three worlds; hetoḥ—for the sake of; kim—what; nu—indeed; mahī-kṛte—for the earth's sake;
nihatya—by killing; dhṛtarāṣṭram—Dhṛtarāṣṭra's sons; naḥ—our; kaḥ prītiḥ syāt—what pleasure will there be; janārdana—O Janārdana (Kṛṣṇa).
verses.translation: Even if we obtained sovereignty of the three worlds by killing Dhṛtarāṣṭra's sons, what joy would there be for us, O Janārdana?
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna rejects political reward: even cosmic gain is meaningless if obtained at the expense of human lives and family bonds.

verses.heading: TEXT 36
transliteration_lines: SvJaNa& ih k-Qa& hTva Saui%Na SYaaMa MaaDav )) 36 ))
word_meaning_lines: pāpam—sin; eva—certainly; āśrayet—will come upon; asmān—us; hatvā—by killing; itān—these; ātatāyinaḥ—aggressors;
tasmāt—therefore; na arhā vayam—not appropriate for us; hantum—to kill; dhṛtarāṣṭrān—sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra; sa-bandhavaḥ—our kinsmen;
sva-janam—our own people; hi—certainly; kathaṁ—how; hatvā—by killing; sukhinaḥ syāma—shall we be happy; mādhava—O Madhava (Kṛṣṇa).
verses.translation: Sin will surely overtake us if we kill those aggressors who are also our kinsmen. How can we be happy by killing our own people, O Mādhava?
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna reasons killing kinsmen is sinful; even if they are transgressors, the moral cost is too great for him to bear.

verses.heading: TEXT 37
word_meaning_lines: yadi—if; api—even; ete—they; na paśyanti—do not see; lobha-upahata-cetasaḥ—driven by greed; kula-kṣaya—destruction of family; kṛtam—caused; doṣaṁ—fault;
mitra-drohe—quarreling with friends; ca—also; pātakam—sinful act.
verses.translation: O Janārdana, though these men, driven by greed, see no fault in destroying family and betraying friends, why should we, who know it's sinful, perform such acts?
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna contrasts the ignorant greed of the enemy with his own knowledge of sin; obligation is not absolute when its consequences are immoral.

verses.heading: TEXT 38
word_meaning_lines: katham—how; na—should not; jñeyam—be known; asmäbhiḥ—by us; pāpāt—from sinful acts; asmāt—ourselves; nivartitum—to desist;
kula-kṣaya—destruction of family; kṛtam—done; prapaśyadbhiḥ—by those who can see; janārdana—O Kṛṣṇa.
verses.translation: How can we, knowing this sin, refrain from stopping it, O Janārdana?
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna appeals to conscience and traditional authority: those who see should avoid sin and prevent it.

verses.heading: TEXT 39
word_meaning_lines: kula-kṣaye—upon destruction of family; praṇaśyanti—are ruined; kula-dharmāḥ—family duties; sanātanāḥ—eternal;
dharme—when dharma is destroyed; naṣṭe—completely; kulaṁ—family; kṛtsnam—entire; adharmo—irreligion; abhibhavat uta—prevails indeed.
verses.translation: When family is destroyed the family’s eternal dharma perishes, and irreligion spreads everywhere.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna explains social consequences: loss of family tradition leads to loss of religion and societal collapse—supporting his reluctance to fight.

verses.heading: TEXT 40
word_meaning_lines: adharmābhibhavat—owing to prevailing irreligion; kṛṣṇa—O Kṛṣṇa; praduṣyanti—are corrupted; kula-striyaḥ—women of the family;
strīṣu—among women; duṣṭāsu—corrupted; varṣeṇa—by degrees; jāyate—arises; varṇa-saṅkaraḥ—mixed progeny (loss of caste order).
verses.translation: When irreligion predominates, family women become corrupt and from their degradation unwanted progeny arises.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna warns of moral degeneration, especially of women and offspring, as a result of family breakdown—this reflects the varṇa-āśrama social concerns in the text.

verses.heading: TEXT 41
word_meaning_lines: saṅkaraḥ—such undesirable progeny; narakāya—leads to hellish life; eva—indeed; kula-ghanānām—of family-destroyers; kulasya ca—of the family also;
patanti—fall; pitaraḥ—forefathers; hi—indeed; eṣām—of them; lupta-pīṇḍa-udaka-kriyāḥ—ritual offerings for forefathers cease.
verses.translation: Such unwanted progeny leads to hell for the family-destroyers; the forefathers fall because the ritual offerings (pinda and water) cease.
purport_paragraphs: Without orthodox rituals and family maintenance, ancestors suffer and social/religious obligations fail, worsening karmic outcomes.

verses.heading: TEXT 42
word_meaning_lines: doṣaiḥ—by these faults; etaiḥ—such; kula-ghanānām—of family-destroyers; varṇa-saṅkara—mixing of castes; kārakaiḥ—causing;
utsādyante—are destroyed; jāti-dharmāḥ—community duties; kula-dharmāḥ—family duties; ca—also; śāśvatāḥ—eternal.
verses.translation: Due to such faults by family-destroyers, the community and family duties are devastated though they should be eternal.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna stresses the far-reaching social damage caused by breakdown of varṇa-āśrama and family traditions.

verses.heading: TEXT 43
word_meaning_lines: utsanna—spoiled; kula-dharmāṇām—of destroyed family-duties; manuṣyāṇām—of men; janārdana—O Kṛṣṇa;
narake—in hell; niyatan—fixed; vāso—residence; bhavati—becomes; iti—thus; anuśruma—I have heard.
verses.translation: I have heard that those who destroy family duties dwell forever in hell, O Janārdana.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna cites authoritative tradition: family destroyers are destined for hell, supporting his moral refusal to fight.

verses.heading: TEXT 44
transliteration_lines: Ahae bTa MahTPaaPa& k-Tau| VYaviSaTaa vYaMa( )
word_meaning_lines: aho bata—alas indeed; mahat pāpam—great sin; kartuṁ—to do; vyavasitā vayam—we are determined; yad—because; rājya-sukha-lobhena—by greed for kingdom and pleasure;
hantuṁ—to kill; sva-janam—own kinsmen; udyatāḥ—prepared to.
verses.translation: Alas, how strange that we are intent on committing great sin, driven by greed for royal pleasure, and aim to slay our kinsmen.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna laments the moral perversity of killing relatives for power; he frames the act as sinful and contrary to dharma.

verses.heading: TEXT 45
word_meaning_lines: yadi—if; mām—to me; apratīkāram—without resistance; aśastram—unarmed; śastra-pāṇayaḥ—with weapons in hand; dhṛtarāṣṭrāḥ—sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra; raṇe—in battle; hanyuḥ—kill;
tat—then; me—my; kṣemataram—safer; bhavet—would be.
verses.translation: If the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra were to kill me unresisting and unarmed, it would be better for me.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna prefers to be slain rather than kill his kin—he expresses readiness to renounce the world rather than commit the sin of kinslaying.

verses.heading: TEXT 46
word_meaning_lines: saïjayaù—Saïjaya; uväca—said; evam uktvā—having thus spoken; arjunaḥ—Arjuna; saṅkhe—in the battlefield; rathaḥ—chariot; upasthaḥ—standing upon; upāviśat—sat down;
visṛjya—throwing away; sa-śaram—his arrows; ca—also; āpam—his bow; śoka—grief; saṁvigna—distressed; mānasaḥ—mind.
verses.translation: Sañjaya said: Having thus spoken, Arjuna, overwhelmed with grief, cast aside his bow and arrows and sat down on the chariot.
purport_paragraphs: Arjuna's grief culminates in refusal to fight; he drops his weapons and awaits Kṛṣṇa's counsel—setting the stage for the Bhagavad-gītā's teaching.
